data.summary: Public health officials confirmed the first two COVID-19 cases in England on 31 January 2020. While a mass vaccination campaign has significantly reduced the number of deaths, the country has seen a sharp uptick in COVID-19 cases driven by the spread of the delta virus variant. Despite high incidence rates, most distancing measures have been lifted.

areaRestrictions.text:
Covid domestic travel policies and advice for:

  • England
  • Scotland
  • Wales
  • Northern Ireland

Northern Ireland

Up to 15 people from four households are permitted to gather in a domestic setting. A one-metre minimum distancing is mandatory in indoor venues.

Scotland

Starting 1 October, a COVID-19 health pass will be required for entering nightlife establishments and large public events. The requirement is expected to apply to unseated indoor live events with more than 500 people in the audience, unseated outdoor live events with more than 4,000 people in the audience and events of any kind with more than 10,000 people present.
Large rallies that have ended in clashes with police have been held in London, Belfast, Manchester, Edinburgh, Leeds, Glasgow, Brighton and other cities to protest lockdown measures.

transportation.text:
Most available long-haul flights are operating at London Heathrow Airport (LHR/EGLL). Multiple carriers including British Airways are gradually increasing their flight schedule.

Flights from Argentina, Bangladesh, Brazil, Cape Verde, Chile, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Egypt, Ethiopia, Indonesia, Kenya, Maldives, Oman, Pakistan, South Africa, Sri Lanka, Tunisia or Turkey are permitted to land at dedicated terminals of London Heathrow (LHR/EGLL) or Birmingham International (BHX/EGBB) airports only.

British Airways suspended all passenger flights between the United Kingdom and Mexico from 15 August to 30 September.

declarationDocuments.text: Arriving travellers must complete and submit a passenger locator form within 48 hours before arrival. Travellers who are arriving from Ireland, the Channel Islands or the Isle of Man and stayed there for at least 10 days are not required to complete the form.

entry.text:
Those who have travelled to or through Afghanistan, Angola, Argentina, Bangladesh, Bolivia, Botswana, Brazil, Burundi, Cape Verde, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), Dominican Republic, Ecuador, Egypt, Eritrea, Eswatini, Ethiopia, French Guiana, Georgia, Guyana, Haiti, Kenya, Lesotho, Malawi, Maldives, Mayotte, Mexico, Mongolia, Montenegro, Mozambique, Myanmar, Namibia, Nepal, Oman, Pakistan, Panama, Paraguay, Peru, Philippines, Reuniion, Rwanda, Seychelles, Sierra Leone, Somalia, South Africa, Sri Lanka, Sudan, Suriname, Tanzania, Thailand, Trinidad and Tobago, Tunisia, Turkey, Uganda, Uruguay, Venezuela, Zambia or Zimbabwe in the last 10 days are not permitted to enter.

Only nationals of the UK and Ireland, UK permanent residents and UK long-term visa holders will be permitted entry from these countries.

diseaseTesting.text:
Before travel

Arriving travellers must present a negative COVID-19 test result not older than three days before the time of departure, regardless of vaccination status. Arrivals from the Common Travel Area (Jersey, Guernsey, the Isle of Man and Ireland), children under the age of 11 and hauliers are exempt. Consult the government website for a full list of testing exemptions (https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/coronavirus-covid-19-travellers-exempt-from-uk-border-rules/coronavirus-covid-19-travellers-exempt-from-uk-border-rules).

After arrival

Travellers must book a post-arrival COVID-19 testing package online (https://quarantinehotelbookings.ctmportal.co.uk/) at their own expense.

Travellers returning from "green list" countries must take an additional PCR test on or before day 2 after arrival. Vaccinated UK travellers returning from abroad and vaccinated travellers from the United States and the European Union must also take a Day 2 test.

Other travellers arriving from an "amber list" country and all travellers returning from a "red list" country must take PCR tests on days 2 and 8 during quarantine.

As part of the 'test to release' scheme, travellers arriving in England from an "amber list" country can take a COVID-19 test five days after entry to shorten the self-quarantine period. Travellers wishing to be tested must do so at their own expense. Travellers must continue to take COVID-19 tests on day 2 and 8 of their stay, regardless of the test result taken as part of the 'test to release' scheme. Travellers arriving from "red list" countries are excluded from the scheme.

tracingApplication.text: Optional contact tracing app "NHS COVID-19" is available for use in England and Wales, "StopCOVID NI" in Northern Ireland and "Protect Scotland" in Scotland.

quarantineModality.text:
Quarantine is mandatory for travellers, excluding those arriving from "green list" areas and vaccinated travellers arriving from some "amber list" areas. For travel from Portugal, quarantine exemptions only apply to arrivals from the Azores or Madeira.

Travellers from "amber list" countries must quarantine for 10 days at home. Vaccinated UK travellers returning from abroad and vaccinated travellers arriving from "amber" countries in the European Union (EU) or the United States (US) are exempt from quarantine.

Travellers who arrive from or stayed in "red list" countries must undergo hotel quarantine at a designated facility for 10 days. The requirement also applies to those who transited through a "red list" country. Travellers arriving from "red list" countries must book a hotel and testing package at their own expense (https://quarantinehotelbookings.ctmportal.co.uk/). The quarantine costs GBP1,750 for the first traveller staying in a room.

Workers in healthcare and other select sectors are exempt from quarantine. Consult the government website (https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/coronavirus-covid-19-travellers-exempt-from-uk-border-rules/coronavirus-covid-19-travellers-exempt-from-uk-border-rules) for further details on quarantine requirements by sector.

England

As part of the "test to release" scheme, travellers may opt to take a test five days into their self-quarantine and leave early, pending a negative test result within 24-48 hours. The testing scheme is not available to travellers arriving from "red list" countries subject to entry bans.

mask.text:
Wearing a face mask is mandatory in public transport and other enclosed public spaces in Northern Ireland, Scotland and Wales.

In England, the use of face masks is recommended in crowded areas. Businesses and travel operators can set their own mask requirements. The use of face masks remains mandatory on public transport operated by Transport for London (TfL).

British Airways passengers are asked to wear a mask from the moment they arrive at the airport until they leave the plane at their destination.

diseaseVaccination.text:
Fully vaccinated travellers arriving from "amber" countries are exempt from quarantine, provided that they were vaccinated in the United Kingdom (UK), an EU member state, Andorra, Iceland, Liechtenstein, Monaco, Norway, San Marino, Switzerland, Vatican City or the United States (US). The vaccine must be recognised by the Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA), US Food and Drug Administration (FDA), European Medicines Agency (EMA) or Swissmedic. To be considered fully vaccinated, travellers must have received two doses of the same vaccine and at least 14 days must have passed since the final dose. Travellers who received one dose of an approved single-dose vaccine are also considered fully vaccinated.

Fully vaccinated travellers arriving from all countries must continue to be tested before departure and on Day 2 after arrival.

Those travelling abroad from Wales or England can present the NHS Covid Pass (https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/coronavirus-covid-19/covid-pass/get-your-covid-pass-letter/) as a digital app or in a letter form as proof of full vaccination from COVID-19. Those travelling from Northern Ireland (https://www.nidirect.gov.uk/services/coronavirus-covid-19-interim-proof-vaccination-document) or Scotland (https://www.nhsinform.scot/covid19status) can obtain the certificate in written form.
qualifiedVaccines: Johnson & Johnson - 14 days after first dose.

areaPolicy.text: Most social distancing measures were lifted in August 2021.

data.summary: Authorities imposed border closures and urged people to avoid travelling and follow social distancing measures over a month after the first COVID-19 cases were detected in the country at the end of January 2020. Cities and provinces were quicker to impose restrictions. The curve of active cases has decreased since early June 2020, prompting many provinces to begin gradually easing COVID-19 measures before a second wave began in early 2021, triggering renewed provincial lockdowns.

areaRestrictions.text:
Greyhound Canada shut down all domestic intercity routes from 13 May.

Effective 8 February, all Air Canada Rouge flights are suspended until further notice. ​

Consult website https://travel.gc.ca/covid-19-provinces-territories for updated internal travel restrictions.
The closure of non-essential businesses, schools and public events differ by province and territory. All essential businesses remain open and public transport is operating.

Anti-lockdown rallies have been held in most major cities, including Ottawa, Hamilton, Montreal, Vancouver, Calgary, Edmonton and Toronto. Protesters have blocked the Trans-Canada Highway on the Nova Scotia-New Brunswick border to demand an end to travel restrictions between provinces.

transportation.text:
International flights may only land at Toronto Pearson (YYZ/CYYZ), Montreal-Trudeau (YUL/CYUL), Vancouver (YVR/CYVR), Calgary (YYC/CYYC) Halifax Stanfield (YHZ/CYHZ), Québec City Jean Lesage (YQB/CYQB), Ottawa Macdonald–Cartier (YOW/CYOW), Winnipeg James Armstrong Richardson (YWG/CYWG) and Edmonton (YEG/CYEG) airports.

Since July 2020, passengers were subject to undergo temperature screening; those with a temperature of 38 degrees Celsius (100.4 Fahrenheit) or higher after two separate tests will not be allowed to proceed to security screening, unless they present a medical certificate indicating that their elevated temperature is not due to COVID-19 (a negative COVID-19 certificate is not sufficient).

Airline passengers, excluding children younger than two and those with disabilities, must wear face masks in transit, excluding masks with an exhalation valve, which are banned, and at screening checkpoints; people lacking protective gear or displaying COVID-19 symptoms like a fever or difficulty breathing will not be allowed to board. Entry to the terminals will be restricted to travellers only; people accompanying minors or individuals with disabilities are exempt.

Porter Airlines extended its ongoing international flight suspension until at least 17 September. Effective 8 February, all Air Canada Rouge flights are suspended until further notice.

From 22 April to 21 September, direct flights from India are banned.

From 29 August to 29 September, direct flights from Morocco are banned.

declarationDocuments.text: Travellers can download the ArriveCAN app or access it online 72 hours prior to entry to submit required information for arrival at an international border crossing, including vaccination status. Arriving travellers must digitally submit their personal information, including travel and contact information, quarantine plan and COVID-19 symptom self-assessment, through the ArriveCAN website before boarding their flights.

entry.text:
The United States (US) and Canadian governments agreed to close the US-Canada border to unvaccinated travellers until 21 September. Fully vaccinated travellers, those engaged in commercial trade and those with cross-border work permits were unaffected.

All travellers who are fully vaccinated against COVID-19 will be permitted to enter Canada without quarantine or post-arrival testing. Foreign nationals who are immediate family members of Canadian citizens or permanent residents and who do not have or display any symptoms of COVID-19, as well as air crew, diplomats, seasonal workers, caregivers and international students are also exempt from the entry ban. Airline passengers will be permitted to transit through Canadian airports.

An ongoing ban on traffic of cruise ships and pleasure crafts with a capacity of at least 100 passengers in Canada's territorial waters was extended until 1 November.

diseaseTesting.text:
Before travel

All inbound international travellers aged 5 and older are required to present a negative COVID-19 PCR or equivalent test obtained within 72 hours prior to departure in order to enter Canada; antigen tests are not accepted. Those without a negative result may face fines of up to CAD 3,000 (USD 2,363).

A list of exemptions to testing is available at https://travel.gc.ca/travel-covid/travel-restrictions/exemptions.

Upon arrival

All unvaccinated travellers must undergo PCR or equivalent testing on arrival. Travellers who can provide a positive COVID-19 test result within 14 to 180 days of arrival are exempt from testing on arrival.

Fully vaccinated travellers may be subject to random arrival testing but are not required to be tested on arrival with proof of vaccination.

A list of exemptions to testing is available at https://travel.gc.ca/travel-covid/travel-restrictions/exemptions.

Designated overland crossing points where tests will be administered are Douglas, British Columbia; Coutts, Alberta; Queenston-Lewiston Bridge, Niagara-on-the-Lake, Ontario; St Bernard de Lacolle (Highway 15), Quebec; St Stephen 3rd Bridge, New Brunswick; Ambassador Bridge, Windsor, Ontario; Blue Water Bridge, Point Edward, Ontario; Emerson West Lynne, Manitoba; Fort Erie (Peace Bridge), Ontario; Huntingdon, British Columbia; Lansdowne (Thousand Islands Bridge), Ontario; Pacific Highway, British Columbia; Rainbow Bridge, Niagara Falls, Ontario; St-Armand, Quebec; Stanstead (Route 55), Quebec and Windsor-Detroit Tunnel, Ontario.

After arrival

All unvaccinated travellers must undergo PCR or equivalent testing on day eight of their self-isolation period. Travellers who can provide a positive COVID-19 test result within 14 to 180 days of arrival are exempt from post-arrival testing.

A list of exemptions to testing is available at https://travel.gc.ca/travel-covid/travel-restrictions/exemptions.
diseaseTesting.when: Before travel, Upon arrival, After arrival
diseaseTesting.testType: PCR, NAAT, LAMP, TMA, CRISPR, NGS

tracingApplication.text: "COVID Alert" is an optional mobile app for the self-assessment of COVID-19 symptoms.

quarantineModality.text:
All unvaccinated travellers entering Canada must self-quarantine for 14 days.

Essential workers, those pre-approved for compassionate reasons and several other categories are exempt from the quarantine requirement. A list of exemptions to testing is available at https://travel.gc.ca/travel-covid/travel-restrictions/exemptions.

Cross-border students are exempt from a mandatory 14-day self-quarantine as are residents of Campobello Island, New Brunswick; Stewart, British Columbia; Northwest Angle, Minnesota; Point Roberts, Washington; and Hyder, Alaska, in the United States (US).

mask.text: Voluntary face mask wearing is encouraged on ferries, trains and buses. Masks must be worn on flights.

exit.text: Foreign nationals in transit through Canada to the US state of Alaska may be subject to additional restrictions at the authorised border crossings at Abbotsford-Huntingdon, Coutts, Kingsgate, North Portal and Osoyoos, including the placement of a "hang tag" on their vehicles indicating their planned date of departure from Canada.

diseaseVaccination.text:
All travellers over the age of 12 who were fully vaccinated against COVID-19 at least 14 days prior to their arrival in Canada will be permitted to enter the country without having to self-isolate or undergo testing on or post-arrival, provided that they take a pre-departure test no later than 72 hours prior to arrival. Proof of vaccination must be submitted on the ArriveCan app prior to arrival.

Travellers who have acquired immunity through previous infection may present a positive test older than 14 days and not older than six months prior to departure to skip on and post-arrival testing.

Federal officials announced that no later than 31 October, government employees as well as all travellers on commercial flights as well as interprovincial ferries/cruises and trains will be required to present proof of COVID-19 vaccination status to board. Authorities did not indicate on what date the policy is expected to begin being enforced but it is likely to begin in mid-September.
qualifiedVaccines: Johnson & Johnson - 14 days after first dose.
Immunity through previous infection - positive test older than 14 days, not older than 6 months.

areaPolicy.text: No national stay at home directive is in place, though social distancing is recommended; provinces and territories have issued their own directives. All vaccinated travellers are allowed entry without restriction.

data.summary: Egypt, the Arab world's most populous country, has registered the second highest COVID-19 death toll in Africa since the outbreak began. Several villages in governorates that are popular with tourists or are home to regular travellers who work or reside in Italy and other European countries, such as Luxor, Aswan and Damietta, have previously been under lockdown, but Cairo and Giza remain the worst-hit areas. Hundreds of new cases continue to be detected on a daily basis and tighter restrictions cannot be ruled out.

areaRestrictions.text: Domestic flights are operating. Public transport services are allowed to operate until 00:00 local time.

Stores, malls, cafes, restaurants, parks and beaches are open.

Hotels are allowed to operate so long as they follow new health guidelines and operate at reduced capacity. The maximum capacity limit at hotels, restaurants, cinemas and theatres is at 70 percent.

transportation.text: All airports have reopened. EgyptAir resumed international flights to Europe, the United Kingdom (UK), Canada, the United States (US) and the rest of the Middle East.

declarationDocuments.text: All travellers must fill in a Health Declaration form, which should be available on all international flights, and present it to Quarantine Authorities upon arrival in Egypt.

entry.text: The border crossing with Rafah in Gaza is open.

diseaseTesting.text:
Before travel

All arriving travellers aged six and older, including Egyptian nationals, must present a negative PCR test result for COVID-19 no older than 72 hours. Travellers arriving from some locations, including Japan, China, Thailand, North America, South America, New Zealand, Australia and Canada, as well as London Heathrow, Paris Charles De Gaulle and Frankfurt airports, will be permitted to enter with a PCR test no older than 96 hours.

Tourists flying into South Sinai, Red Sea and Matrouh governorates without a PCR test will be subject to testing on arrival at a cost of 30USD.

Only paper copies of the test results are accepted.

Upon arrival

Travellers entering the country from locations which have high instances of COVID-19 variants will be requested to undergo a test to confirm their negative PCR test.

tracingApplication.text: There is no national contact tracing app.

quarantineModality.text:
There is no requirement for foreign travellers arriving at any airport to quarantine. Only those showing symptoms will be forced to isolate at a local hospital.

Tourists flying into South Sinai, Red Sea and Matrouh governorates who are subject to testing on arrival are required to self-quarantine at their hotel until a result is obtained (usually within 24 hours). If testing positive, travellers will be required to self-isolate for 14 days in a separate part of the hotel allocated for quarantine.

mask.text: Face masks or coverings are mandatory in public; passengers will not be allowed to board vehicles unless they are masked.

diseaseVaccination.text: Travellers who were fully vaccinated at least 14 days prior to departure with COVID-19 vaccines approved by Egyptian authorities or the WHO, except those who were in countries/regions with mutated variants of COVID-19 including India, Bangladesh, Pakistan, Bhutan, Myanmar, Nepal, Vietnam, Sri Lanka, Brazil and other Latin American countries during the previous 14 days, were allowed to enter without a negative PCR test result for COVID-19.
qualifiedVaccines: Johnson & Johnson - 14 days after first dose.
Sputnik V - 14 days after second dose.
Sinopharm Phase 2 - 14 days after second dose.

areaPolicy.text: Some restrictions on movement and business operations remain in force until further notice.

data.summary: Sweden confirmed its first novel coronavirus (COVID-19) case on 31 January 2020 after a traveller from Wuhan, China, tested positive for the virus in Jönköping County. Sweden responded to the outbreak with a relatively lax approach, being one of the few countries without mandatory mask use in public spaces. While sanitary measures are being eased in stages, the country's COVID-19 laws remain in effect until January 2022.

areaRestrictions.text: Private gatherings are permitted for up to 50 people. On 29 September, limits on the size of public and private events will be lifted.
Prince Carl Philip and Princess Sofia tested postive for COVID-19 on 26 November 2020.
Clashes erupted during a march from Stockholm's Medborgarplatsen in March 2021 between police and anti-lockdown demonstrators.

transportation.text: Scandinavian Airlines (SAS), the main airline serving the country, is operating flights through Stockholm Arlanda Airport (ARN/ESSA) primarily to destinations in Scandinavia and major hubs in Europe. Long-haul service is available on a limited number of routes, including ones linking Stockholm to destinations in the United States, China and the United Arab Emirates.

entry.text:
An entry ban is in effect for travellers arriving from a country outside the European Union (EU) and the Schengen Area until 31 October. Nationals of Sweden and other European Economic Area (EEA) countries and residents of Albania, Armenia, Australia, Azerbaijan, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Brunei, Canada, Hong Kong, Japan, Jordan, Macau, Moldova, New Zealand, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Serbia, Singapore, South Korea, Taiwan and Ukraine are exempt and permitted to enter.

Exemptions are also made for those with an essential need or function in Sweden, returning Swedish residents and new residency or student permit holders who are to moving to Sweden. Travellers considered to have an essential purpose include health care professionals, workers transporting goods and passengers travelling for imperative family reasons. The decision to grant an exemption will be made at the border upon arrival; police do not issue prior approvals.

diseaseTesting.text:
Before travel

EU travellers - excluding residents of Sweden and travellers from Denmark, Finland, Norway and Iceland - must present the EU Digital COVID Certificate or equivalent documentation as proof of a negative COVID-19 test, recovery or vaccination. The test must have been taken within 72 hours before entry. Cross-border commuters must present a negative COVID-19 test that is no older than one week.

Swedish nationals and others exempt from pre-departure testing are advised to be tested as soon as possible after arrival and take a second test on Day 5. Testing centres can be found on website https://www.1177.se/.

Non-EU travellers are required to present a negative PCR, LAMP, TMA or antigen test for COVID-19 no older than 48 hours before arrival.
diseaseTesting.testType: PCR, Antigen, LAMP, TMA, PCR, Antigen, LAMP, TMA

tracingApplication.text: There is no national contact tracing app.

quarantineModality.text: There is no requirement for international arrivals to quarantine. However, non-EU arrivals are recommended to self-quarantine for up to seven days and avoid close contact with others.

mask.text: SAS passengers must wear face medical masks while on board. Travellers showing symptoms of COVID-19 will be denied boarding.

exit.text: Non-essential travel to countries outside the EU, the Schengen Area and the UK is discouraged until 15 October. The advice does not apply to travel to non-EU countries that are exempt from Sweden's entry ban.

diseaseVaccination.text:
Travellers who present the EU Digital COVID Certificate (EUDCC) or other valid proof of recovery or vaccination against COVID-19 are exempt from testing. Proof of vaccination or recovery is only valid for entry or transit from another EEA country.

Vaccination certificates must have been issued in an EEA country, Andorra, Monaco, San Marino, Switzerland, the Vatican or a "safe" non-EU country to be considered valid. The vaccine must have been approved by the European Medicines Agency (EMA) or the World Health Organization (WHO) for emergency use.

Proof of recovery must be issued in an EEA country, Andorra, Monaco, San Marino, Switzerland or the Vatican to be considered valid.
qualifiedVaccines: AstraZeneca (South Korea) - 14 days after second dose.
Johnson & Johnson - 14 days after first dose.
Sinopharm Phase 1 - 14 days after second dose.
Immunity through previous infection - positive test older than 11 days, not older than 6 months.

areaPolicy.text: As part of a five-step reopening plan, social distancing requirements and limits on gatherings are being lifted gradually. Most COVID-19 measures will be lifted on 29 September.

data.summary: Authorities have imposed a combination of lockdowns and travel bans to limit the spread of the virus nationwide, but cases have since continued to rise. Limited testing capacity and lack of healthcare infrastructure have complicated efforts to respond to the crisis. Although a vaccination roll-out is ongoing, only 1.3 percent of the population is fully vaccinated.

areaRestrictions.text: A curfew from 23:00-05:00 local time is in effect nationwide.

Public transport and taxis are operational.

Only vaccinated travellers are permitted entry to Dhi Qar governorate.

Shopping malls, restaurants, cafes, cinemas, parks, event, sports and wedding halls may reopen daily until 20:30 local time.

Iraqi Kurdistan

The Kurdistan Regional Government (KRG) has imposed restrictions on movement and businesses. Refer to https://gov.krd/coronavirus-en/situation-update/ for updates.
While all public gatherings are banned, anti-government protests continue to take place and are routinely dispersed by the security forces.

transportation.text:
Commercial flights resumed at Baghdad (BGW/ORBI), Najaf (NJF/ORNI) and Basra (BSR/ORMM) international airports, as well as at Erbil (EBL/ORER) and Sulaimaniyah (ISU/ORSU) airports in Iraqi Kurdistan.

Flights from India and Bangladesh are banned until further notice.

entry.text:
Citizens of the United States, United Kingdom, Russia, China, Japan, South Korea, Canada, Australia, New Zealand, Switzerland and European Union (EU) countries were allowed to pay for a two-month visa on arrival, effective 15 March, as part of a government drive to encourage investment and support job creation.

Travellers from India and Bangladesh are banned from entering Iraq until further notice.

Iranian officials have periodically closed all border crossings with Iraq.

diseaseTesting.text:
Before travel

Travellers arriving by air must present a negative PCR test for COVID-19 no older than 72 hours prior to boarding.

Kurdistan Region of Iraq requires all travellers to submit a COVID-19 PCR test that is no older than 48 hours or verified evidence of a second dose of vaccination. Those without either will be required to undertake a PCR test at the airport upon arrival, at their own expense.

tracingApplication.text: There is no national contact tracing app.

quarantineModality.text: All individuals are required to self-quarantine for 14 days. Official delegations, business people and tourists on short stay trips are not required to self-quarantine in the Kurdistan region if they have a negative PCR test.

mask.text: Face masks are mandatory in public and violators of the order are subject to fines. In the Kurdistan Region, the use of face masks is also mandatory in public and private sector institutions and in vehicles. Failure to comply with the rules may result in a fine of IQD20,000 to 50,000 (USD14-34).

exit.text: All outbound international travellers must present a negative PCR result that is no older than 72 hours.

otherRestriction.text: Screening measures are in effect and all passengers must wear masks inside airports following the resumption of flights.

diseaseVaccination.text: Fully vaccinated individuals travelling to the Kurdistan Region of Iraq are exempt from pre-departure testing provided they present proof of vaccination. Further details on which vaccines and certificates were not immediately available.

areaPolicy.text:
A nightly curfew is in effect nationwide until further notice.

Officials in the Kurdistan region have imposed periodic nightly curfews and inter-governorate travel bans.

data.summary: The UAE initially kept cases and fatalities low after imposing stringent curfews and lockdowns to prevent the spread of COVID-19. However, as of late-August 2021, around 1000 new cases are being detected per day, and tighter restrictions could once again be implemented.

areaRestrictions.text:
Abu Dhabi

All travellers to the emirate of Abu Dhabi will be required to present a negative PCR test result no older than 48 hours and undergo additional testing on days four and eight if staying longer, or present a negative DPI test result no older than 24 hours, and undergo additional testing on days three and seven if staying longer. Proof of testing must be presented on the Al Hosn app or via text message.

Public transport is operating at 50 percent capacity.

People who have tested positive for COVID-19 or been in contact with those who have must wear electronic wristbands with the Alhosn COVID-19 app installed for testing and tracing cases. Wearers must self-quarantine and violators are subject to an AED10,000 (USD2,733) fine. Two consecutive negative tests are required for a clean bill of health. Further details can be found on: https://www.ncema.gov.ae/alhosn/index.html.

Abu Dhabi

Hospitality establishments can open at 50 percent capacity. Access to public venues such as shopping malls, supermarkets, gyms, hotels, public parks, beaches, pools, entertainment centres, cinemas, museums, restaurants and cafes, is limited to individuals who have obtained a green pass on the Alhosn app. The green pass will be dependent on vaccination status and PCR testing.

The use of the green pass system was temporarily suspended from 18 June due to a technical fault with the Alhosn app.

transportation.text:
Emirates and Etihad Airways flights are operating to international destinations in the Middle East, Europe, Africa, Southeast Asia and North and South America, with capacity increasing weekly.

A ban on flights to and from Afghanistan, Bangladesh, the Democratic Republic of Congo, Indonesia, Liberia, Namibia, Nigeria, Sierra Leone, Vietnam and Zambia is in effect until further notice.

Flights to and from Saudi Arabia are suspended until further notice.

declarationDocuments.text: Travellers entering Ras Al Khaimah must complete a health disclosure form upon arrival.

entry.text:
The issuance of visitor, residence and tourist permits across all emirates has resumed.

Most foreign travellers who have visited Afghanistan, Bangladesh, the Democratic Republic of Congo, India, Indonesia, Liberia, Namibia, Nepal, Nigeria, Pakistan, Sierra Leone, South Africa, Vietnam and Zambia within 14 days prior to departure are banned from entering the UAE until further notice. UAE nationals and their relatives, residents with gold or silver residency permits, transit travellers, fully vaccinated foreign tourists, as well as essential travellers, including diplomats and some businesspeople, are exempt from the ban. Fully vaccinated foreign residents, as well as unvaccinated medical personnel, workers in the education sector, students, residents with extenuating circumstances, people undergoing medical treatment and government employees arriving from India, Pakistan, Sri Lanka, Nepal, Nigeria and Uganda are also allowed entry into the UAE.

All seaports are closed to passenger cruise ships. Abu Dhabi is expected to allow cruise ships to dock from September.

Starting 1 September, land borders reopened to travellers from Oman.

diseaseTesting.text:
Before travel

Generally, all inbound and transit travellers must pre-book a COVID-19 PCR test in an accredited laboratory at a port of departure within 96 hours prior to arrival; only travellers who receive a negative result will be allowed entry. Children under the age of 12 and passengers who have a moderate or severe disability are exempt.

Eligible travellers from Liberia, Namibia, Sierra Leone, the Democratic Republic of Congo, Uganda, Zambia, Vietnam, Pakistan, Bangladesh, Nepal, Sri Lanka, India, Nigeria and South Africa must submit a PCR test dated within 48 hours and take a PCR test on day four and eight after arrival. Eligible travellers from India, Pakistan, Sri Lanka, Nepal, and Uganda also needed a PCR rapid test four hours before their flight departure.

Starting 1 September, travellers arriving by land from Oman must present a negative PCR test that was taken within 48 hours before arrival and take a rapid test at the border. Travellers whose stay is four days or longer must take another PCR test on the fourth day. Travellers whose stay is eight days or longer must take another PCR test on the eighth day.

Entry restrictions differ depending upon which Emirate you are travelling to.

Dubai

All travellers to the emirate, including residents and Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) citizens, will be required to present a negative PCR test result no older than 72 hours, and submit to additional testing upon arrival depending on the point of origin. Further details are available via https://www.emirates.com/uk/english/help/covid-19/dubai-travel-requirements/tourists/.

Upon arrival

People arriving on tourist visas must take a rapid PCR test on arrival.

After arrival

Entry restrictions differ depending upon which Emirate you are travelling to.

Abu Dhabi

International travellers arriving directly into Abu Dhabi must also take a PCR test on arrival, as well as a PCR test on the 6th and 12th day of their stay; travellers staying for less than six or 12 days are exempt from further testing.

Vaccinated travellers arriving from ‘green’ countries must take a PCR test on arrival and on day 6. Vaccinated travellers arriving from other countries must take PCR tests on day 4 and 8 after arrival.

Sharjah

International travellers arriving into Sharjah must take a PCR test on arrival.

Ras Al Khaimah

Travellers entering Ras Al Khaimah must undergo a second test upon arrival.

Foreign government officials may be exempt from testing depending on their role and position within their respective governments.
diseaseTesting.when: Before travel, Upon arrival, After arrival

tracingApplication.text:
Authorities advised individuals to download the TraceCovid App for contact tracing.

Those in quarantine are required to download the AlHosn App.

quarantineModality.text:
All nationals and other exempted travellers returning from Liberia, Namibia, Sierra Leone, the Democratic Republic of Congo, Uganda, Zambia, Vietnam, Pakistan, Bangladesh, Nepal, Sri Lanka, India, Nigeria and South Africa South Africa or Nigeria must self-quarantine for 10 days on arrival.

Abu Dhabi

Travellers entering Abu Dhabi from 'green' countries are exempt from quarantine but must take a test on arrival and on the 6th and 12th days after arrival. All other travellers must self-quarantine for 10 days and take a PCR test on day 8. A list of 'green' countries is subject to renewal every two weeks and is available at: https://visitabudhabi.ae/en/plan-your-trip/covid-safe-travel/permitted-countries.

Vaccinated travellers entering Abu Dhabi are exempt from quarantine, but a vaccination certificate must be registered on the Federal Authority for Identity and Citizenship (ICA) website or app.

Dubai

Only travellers who take a PCR test on arrival into Dubai are required to self-quarantine until test results are known. If positive, they will be required to isolate. Asymptomatic travellers, those showing mild symptoms and those that have come into contact with positive cases may isolate for 10 days as opposed to 14.

Sharjah

Travellers arriving into Sharjah must self-quarantine until the results from the PCR test taken on arrival are available. If positive, they must self-isolate for 14 days.

Ras Al Khaimah

Travellers must self-quarantine until the results of the PCR test taken on arrival are available. If positive, travellers, will be required to isolate.

mask.text: People must wear masks at all times in public, violators will face legal action.

diseaseVaccination.text:
Holders of COVID-19 vaccination certificates issued in Serbia are exempt from quarantine upon arrival. A similar measure is in effect for vaccinated travellers from the Seychelles.

Fully vaccinated foreign residents are permitted entry from India, Pakistan, Sri Lanka, Nepal, Nigeria and Uganda provided they have received both doses of a vaccine in the UAE, at least 14 days have passed since the second dose, and they have a vaccination certificate approved by Emirati authorities. Vaccination status must be registered online (https://smartservices.ica.gov.ae/echannels/web/client/guest/#/registerArrivals).

Vaccinated travellers entering Abu Dhabi are exempt from quarantine on arrival. They may also be exempt from some testing requirements depending on their country of departure.

In Abu Dhabi, only those who have been vaccinated against COVID-19 will be permitted to enter certain public spaces, including universities, schools, resorts, shopping centres, restaurants, cafes and other retail outlets. Supermarkets and pharmacies will remain accessible regardless of vaccination status.
qualifiedVaccines: AstraZeneca (South Korea) - 14 days after second dose.
Johnson & Johnson - 28 days after first dose.
Sinopharm Phase 1 - 14 days after second dose.

areaPolicy.text: Most businesses have been allowed to reopen but capacity restrictions remain in effect along with social distancing measures.

data.summary: One of the first countries in Europe to be hit by the outbreak, Italy confirmed its first two COVID-19 cases on 30 January 2020 after two Chinese tourists on a cruise ship off Civitavecchia tested positive for the virus. In June 2021, all regions of the country were assessed to be low-risk ("white"), allowing most restrictions to be lifted. A state of emergency is in effect until 31 December.

areaRestrictions.text: A COVID-19 green pass is mandatory for inter-regional travel. The requirement will not apply to local transport, intra-regional transport or ferry links on the Strait of Messina between Sicily and Calabria.

A COVID-19 green pass is required to attend sporting events and other large public events and to visit indoor venues, including restaurants, bars and cinemas. The pass must show receipt of at least one COVID-19 vaccine dose, recovery from an infection within the last six months or a negative COVID-19 test taken within 48 hours. Starting 1 September, the pass is also mandatory for university students.

Nightlife establishments are closed.

Sicily is subject to stricter "yellow"-level measures. At restaurants, a maximum of four customers is permitted per table.

Multiple protests have been held against the government's COVID-19 policies - including lockdowns, curfew order, restrictions on the hospitality industry and mandatory use of the COVID-19 "green pass" in certain spaces - with some demonstrations spiralling into clashes with police.
On 2 July 2020, private and public health care workers held a general strike to demand an increase in health funding and hiring and improvements to working conditions.

transportation.text: International flights are available, primarily to neighbouring countries and major hubs in Europe. Flights are also available on a limited number of long-distance routes, including Rome Fiumicino (FCO/LIRF)-John F. Kennedy (JFK/KJFK) and Milan Malpensa (MXP/LIMC)-John F. Kennedy (JFK/KJFK).

declarationDocuments.text:
Arriving travellers must complete the EU Digital Passenger Locator Form (https://app.euplf.eu/#/).

Registration is also required for travel to Puglia (https://www.sanita.puglia.it/web/pugliasalute/ingresso-in-puglia-da-estero).

entry.text:
Entry is permitted from "Category C" countries - EU and Schengen Area countries, Andorra, Monaco and Israel - provided that arrivals only transited or stayed in countries where entry is permitted in the last 14 days. There are no restrictions on entry from San Marino and Vatican City ("Category A").

Travellers from "Category D" countries - Albania, Armenia, Australia, Azerbaijan, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Brunei, Canada, Hong Kong, Japan, Jordan, Kosovo, Lebanon, Macau, Moldova, Montenegro, New Zealand, North Macedonia, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Serbia, Singapore, South Korea, Taiwan, Ukraine, the United Arab Emirates (UAE), the United Kingdom (UK) and the United States (US) - are also permitted entry. However, "Category D" travellers without proof of vaccination and negative test for COVID-19 are generally subject to quarantine.

Non-essential travel from other non-EU/Schengen countries ("Category E") is banned. EU nationals and long-term residents and those seeking to travel for work, absolute urgency, health, study or return home are exempt.

Travellers who stayed or transited in Bangladesh, India or Sri Lanka in the last 14 days are banned from entering Italy. Students, parents of minor children residing in Italy, partners of Italian residents, those who had registered residence in Italy before 28 August and Italian nationals registered in the Registry of Italians Residing Abroad (AIRE) are exempt.

Travellers who stayed or transited in Brazil in the last 14 days are banned from entering Italy. Students, military personnel, parents of minor children residing in Italy, only those who had registered residence in Italy before 13 February are exempt and permitted entry.

diseaseTesting.text:
Before travel

Travellers arriving the European Union (EU), the Schengen Area and Israel must present the EU Digital COVID Certificate (EUDCC) or equivalent proof of a negative test, recovery or vaccination against COVID-19. The test must be a PCR or antigen test that was taken within 48 hours before entry.

Non-EU arrivals - excluding UK travellers - must present a negative PCR or antigen test that was taken within 72 hours before arrival. Those who fail to present a negative test will be subject to quarantine, regardless of recovery or vaccination status.

UK arrivals must present a negative PCR or antigen test that was taken within 48 hours before arrival. Those who fail to present a negative test will be subject to quarantine, regardless of recovery or vaccination status.

Upon arrival

Travellers who are permitted to arrive from Bangladesh, Brazil, India or Sri Lanka must take a COVID-19 test within 48 hours of arrival, in addition to testing before departure and at the end of the quarantine period.

After arrival

Travellers who are subject to quarantine upon arrival must take a COVID-19 test at the end of the quarantine period.
diseaseTesting.when: Before travel, Upon arrival, After arrival

tracingApplication.text: "Immuni" (https://www.immuni.italia.it/) is a voluntary mobile app for contact tracing available on Android and iOS devices.

quarantineModality.text:
Arrivals from EU/Schengen countries, Andorra, Monaco and Israel ("Category C") must present proof of a negative COVID-19 test, recovery or vaccination to be exempt from quarantine. "Category C" arrivals who fail to present COVID-19 documentation must self-quarantine for five days.

Travellers from non-EU countries that are in "Category D" must quarantine for five days. Travellers with proof of vaccination and a negative COVID-19 test are exempt from quarantine. Travellers from Canada, Japan, the United States and the United Kingdom can also present proof of recovery instead of proof of vaccination to be exempt from quarantine.

Travellers from other non-EU countries ("Category E") must quarantine for 10 days.

Arrivals from San Marino and the Vatican are exempt from quarantine. Transport workers, those who are travelling for proven work, health or urgency and whose stay does not exceed 120 hours, those whose transit by private vehicle does not exceed 36 hours, cross-border workers and healthcare workers are also exempt from quarantine.

mask.text:
Face masks must be worn on public transport and in indoor spaces, as well as crowded outdoor areas.

In Sicily, a face mask must be worn in both indoor and outdoor spaces.

exit.text: Leisure travel to countries in Category E - non-EU countries excluding Israel and Category D countries - is not permitted. Travelling to Category E countries is only permitted for work, health, study, absolute urgency or return home.

diseaseVaccination.text:
Arrivals from the European Union (EU) and the Schengen Area can present the EU Digital Covid Certificate or another proof of vaccination or recovery to be exempt from testing and quarantine. The vaccination certificate must show that at least 14 days have passed since the final dose.

Travellers arriving from Canada, Israel, Japan, the United Kingdom (UK) and the United States (US) with proof of recovery or vaccination against COVID-19 are exempt from quarantine, provided that they also present a negative COVID-19 test that was taken within 72 hours of arrival. Travellers arriving from other "Category D" non-EU countries must present proof of vaccination and a negative COVID-19 test to be exempt from quarantine.

Residents can obtain the the EU Digital Covid Certificate (EUDCC) online (https://www.dgc.gov.it/web/) as proof of vaccination, recovery or a negative test for COVID-19. The test cannot be older than 48 hours. The certificate can be used to attend large public events and accepted in both paper and electronic format. COVID-19 certificates issued in Canada, Israel, Japan, UK and US will be considered equivalent to the EUDCC.
qualifiedVaccines: Johnson & Johnson - 14 days after first dose.
Immunity through previous infection - positive test older than 11 days, not older than 6 months.

areaPolicy.text:
A COVID-19 'green pass' is required for access to certain public venues and services. In September, the requirement to present the certificate will be extended to long-distance travel.

Regions are assessed "white" (lowest risk), "yellow" (lower risk), "orange" (medium risk) or "red" (high risk) depending on the severity of the epidemiological situation. All regions excluding Sicily are "white".

data.summary: On 27 February 2020, public health officials confirmed the first case of the novel coronavirus (COVID-19) in Tilburg after a patient who recently travelled to northern Italy tested positive for the disease. The country has since seen multiple waves of COVID-19 infections. Following a surge in cases due to the delta virus variant, tightened sanitary measures are in effect until 19 September.

areaRestrictions.text:
Nightlife establishments are closed. Until 19 September, hospitality establishments must close by 00:00 local time. Seated indoor events that do not require a COVID-19 health pass for entry are limited to two-thirds capacity. Multi-day festivals are banned.

On 20 September, a COVID-19 entry pass system is expected to take effect for access to hospitality establishments and large events. The entry pass can be obtained with proof of vaccination, recovery or a negative test that was taken within 24 hours before entry.

Multiple demonstrations have been held in protest of lockdown measures and over the economic impact of the pandemic. Dozens of anti-lockdown protesters were detained amid a demonstration at Koekamp in The Hague on 5 May 2020 for not complying with social distancing measures. In late January 2021, dozens of people were detained and multiple buildings were damaged in Amsterdam, Rotterdam, Den Bosch, Haarlem, Tilburg, Veenendaal, Breda, Almelo, Zwolle, Helmond, Geleen, Enschede, Urk, Stein, The Hague and Eindhoven during riots over the government's decision to impose a curfew.

transportation.text: Flights are predominantly operating to and from European destinations. Limited long-haul flights resumed on multiple routes, including flights between Amsterdam Schiphol (AMS/EHAM) and John F. Kennedy (JFK/KJFK), Los Angeles (LAX/KLAX) and Toronto Pearson (YYZ/CYYZ) airports.

declarationDocuments.text:
All travellers must complete a health declaration form to confirm that they do not have COVID-19 symptoms.

Travellers arriving from very high COVID-19 risk countries must also complete a quarantine declaration (https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/documents/publications/2021/05/26/quarantine-declaration).

Vaccinated travellers must complete a vaccine declaration (https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/documents/publications/2021/07/01/vaccine-declaration-covid-19), in addition to presenting proof of vaccination at the border.

entry.text:
Non-essential travel is not permitted from most non-European Union (EU) countries. Long-term residents of Albania, Armenia, Australia, Azerbaijan, Bosnia-Herzegovina, Brunei, Canada, Faroe Islands, Greenland, Hong Kong, Japan, Jordan, Macau, Moldova, New Zealand, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Serbia, Singapore, South Korea, Svalbard, Taiwan and Ukraine are exempt and permitted entry. Cross-border workers, workers in the transport sector and those seeking to enter for urgent family reasons are also exempt. Business travellers are permitted entry for urgent travel that cannot be postponed; business travellers must present at the border a note issued by a Dutch embassy confirming the exemption, proof of accommodation and proof of a return ticket, as well as a visa if required.

Nationals and residents of an EU member state, Schengen Area country, Monaco, San Marino or the Vatican are permitted entry regardless of purpose.

diseaseTesting.text:
Before travel

Travellers who arrive from EU countries without proof of recovery or vaccination against COVID-19 must present a negative nucleic acid amplification test (PCR, RT-PCR, LAMP, TMA, mPOCT) taken within 48 hours or an antigen test within 24 hours.

Non-EU travellers arriving from a "safe" or high-risk area without proof of vaccination against COVID-19 must present a negative NAAT test taken within 48 hours or an antigen test within 24 hours.

Travellers arriving from very high-risk areas must present a negative test, regardless of recovery or vaccination status.

After arrival

After arrival, travellers undergoing self-quarantine can reduce the quarantine period by taking a second COVID-19 test five days after entry and obtaining a negative result. Travellers can arrange testing by calling local health authorities (GGD) on 0800 1202 (or +31 850 659 063) or online (coronatest.nl).
diseaseTesting.testType: PCR, NAAT, LAMP, TMA, mPOCT, Antigen, PCR, NAAT, LAMP, TMA, mPOCT, Antigen

tracingApplication.text: Voluntary contact tracing app "CoronaMelder" (https://coronamelder.nl/en/) is available for use on mobile devices.

quarantineModality.text:
Travellers returning from very high COVID-19 risk countries must self-quarantine for up to 10 days upon arrival, regardless of vaccination status. A PCR test can be taken on day five to end quarantine early. Quarantine requirements can be confirmed on the Dutch government website (https://reizentijdenscorona.rijksoverheid.nl/en).

Cross-border commuters (including students), transport workers and those travelling to visit a partner, spouse, child or parent are exempt from quarantine. Temporarily leaving self-quarantine is permitted for select purposes, including making business trips that contribute to Dutch economic and societal interests, conducting research in the field of healthcare, going to work or attending a funeral. A full list of exemptions is available on the Dutch government website (https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/visiting-the-netherlands-from-abroad/self-quarantine/exemptions).

mask.text: Face masks must be worn on public transport and transit hubs, as well as crowded spaces where a 1.5-metre minimum distance cannot be kept.

exit.text: Travel is not advised to non-EU countries that are colour-coded "orange" or "red" for COVID-19 risk level. Travel advice will be published on website wijsopreis.nl.

diseaseVaccination.text:
Frpm 4 September, only travellers with proof of full vaccination or exempted travellers are permitted entry from non-EU countries. Travellers from a high-risk area are required to show proof of vaccination, or recovery, or a negative COVID-19 test result, and the health declaration. Travellers from a very high-risk area must quarantine for 10 days from arrival from 4 September and complete the health declaration, and also show a negative test result from 09:00 on 6 September.

The vaccine must have been approved by the European Medicines Agency (EMA) or the World Health Organization (WHO) for emergency use. The certificate must be issued in Dutch, English, French, German, Italian, Portuguese or Spanish.

Travellers from high-risk EU countries are required to show proof of vaccination, or recovery, or a negative test result from 09:00 on 6 September.

A proof of vaccination, recovery or negative test for COVID-19 can be presented for access to large events, including festivals and sporting events. Dutch residents can use the CoronaCheck App (https://coronacheck.nl/en) as a COVID-19 certificate. A print-out of the QR code generated by the app will be accepted as well.
qualifiedVaccines: AstraZeneca (South Korea) - 14 days after second dose.
Johnson & Johnson - 28 days after first dose.
Sinopharm Phase 1 - 14 days after second dose.
Immunity through previous infection - positive test older than 11 days, not older than 6 months.
diseaseVaccination.exemptions: Domestic Restrictions, Testing, Quarantine, Entry Ban

areaPolicy.text: A 1.5-metre social distancing requirement for most venues and other sanitary measures are in effect until 19 September inclusive.

data.summary: The COVID-19 outbreak in Spain caused one of the highest number of deaths in Europe. In January 2021, the total number of cases in the country surpassed 2 million. While most restrictions have been eased following the end of the state of alarm in May 2021, thousands of new cases continue to be reported daily.

areaRestrictions.text: A negative COVID-19 test is required for travel to the Balearic Islands and the Canary Islands. Travellers who have recovered from COVID-19 or have been vaccinated against the virus are exempt.

Hundreds of demonstrators rallied on Puerta del Sol and outside the Assembly of Madrid in Puente de Vallecas on 27 September 2020 to protest lockdown measures in the capital. In October and November 2020, clashes erupted between demonstrators and police officers in Barcelona, Seville, León, Logroño and Vitoria-Gasteiz during protests against the goverment's decision to impose a nighttime curfew. Further protests are possible, particularly in urban hubs.

transportation.text: International flights are operating at major airports, including Barcelona-El Prat (BCN/LEBL), Madrid–Barajas (MAD/LEMD), Ibiza (IBZ/LEIB), Menorca (MAH/LEMH), Tenerife South (TFS/GCTS), Alicante-Elche (ALC/LEAL), Region of Murcia (RMU/LEMI), Sevilla (SVQ/LEZL), Málaga (AGP/LEMG), Palma de Mallorca (PMI/LEPA) and Gran Canaria (LPA/GCLP).

declarationDocuments.text:
Travellers arriving by air must complete a health control form (https://www.spth.gob.es/) 48 hours prior to travel and obtain a QR code to present upon arrival. The form can be also completed on the mobile app "Spain Travel Health APP".

Travellers arriving by sea must complete a separate form (https://spthm.puertos.es/).

Travellers arriving in Galicia must provide contact details by completing a form (https://coronavirus.sergas.gal/viaxeiros/?ling=en) if they visited a high COVID-19 risk area in the last 14 days.

entry.text:
Entry by nationals of non-European Union (EU)/Schengen Area countries is banned through 30 September. Residents of EU and Schengen Area countries, Andorra, Monaco, San Marino and the Vatican, holders of long-term visas issued in EU member states and Schengen Area countries returning to the country of their residence, healthcare workers, transport workers and diplomatic personnel are exempt. Residents of Albania, Armenia, Australia, Azerbaijan, Bosnia-Herzegovina, Brunei, Canada, China, Japan, Jordan, Moldova, New Zealand, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Serbia, Singapore, South Korea, Ukraine, Hong Kong, Macau, Kosovo and Taiwan are also exempt. A negative test or proof of vaccination against COVID-19 is required for entry from the United Kingdom (UK). Proof of COVID-19 vaccination is required for non-essential travel from other non-EU countries.

Borders with other EU member states and Schengen countries are open.

Cruise ships are permitted to dock in Spanish ports.

diseaseTesting.text:
Before travel

Travellers arriving from high COVID-19 risk countries must present a certificate for a nucleic acid amplification test (PCR, TMA, LAMP, NEAR) taken within 72 hours or an antigen test that was taken within 48 hours before arrival; travellers who present proof of full vaccination against COVID-19 or recovery from a prior infection are exempt. The certificate must be in Spanish, English, French or German. The list of countries subject to testing will be updated weekly by health officials.

Transiting passengers are exempt from testing, provided that they do not leave the international zone. Travellers arriving from high-risk countries without a test result will be required to take a test upon arrival and subject to a fine of up to EUR6,000 (USD7,095).

Travellers arriving from the United Kingdom (UK) must present a negative nucleic acid amplification test that was taken within 72 hours before arrival or proof of full vaccination against the virus.
diseaseTesting.testType: PCR, NAAT, LAMP, TMA, NEAR, Antigen, PCR, NAAT, LAMP, TMA, NEAR

tracingApplication.text: "Radar Covid" is an optional mobile app for contact tracing.

mask.text: Wearing a face mask is compulsory in all indoor spaces, as well as crowded outdoor areas where a 1.5-metre minimum distance cannot be maintained among members of different households.

otherRestriction.text: All passengers arriving by air and sea will undergo a temperature check. Those suspected of having COVID-19 will be subject to an additional health assessment.

diseaseVaccination.text:
Fully vaccinated travellers are permitted entry regardless of purpose and exempt from COVID-19 testing. The vaccine must be approved by the European Medicines Agency (EMA) or the World Health Organization (WHO).

Travellers who recovered from a prior infection are exempt from pre-departure testing.

Accepted documentation include the EU Digital COVID Certificate or an equivalent certificate showing that at least 14 days have passed since the final dose or a positive nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT) was issued between 11-180 days before arrival.
qualifiedVaccines: AstraZeneca (South Korea) - 14 days after second dose.
Johnson & Johnson - 14 days after first dose.
Sinopharm Phase 1 - 14 days after second dose.
Immunity through previous infection - positive test older than 11 days, not older than 6 months.

areaPolicy.text: Regional authorities tightened COVID-19 measures following an increase in cases.
